name: Divalproex Sodium (Depakote)
summary: An anticonvulsant and mood stabilizer used for bipolar disorder, epilepsy, and migraine prophylaxis.
description: Divalproex sodium is a compound of sodium valproate and valproic acid in a 1:1 ratio, designed to improve gastrointestinal tolerability. It is widely used in psychiatry as a mood stabilizer for acute mania, mixed episodes, and maintenance in bipolar disorder. Additionally, it is prescribed for seizure disorders and migraine prophylaxis.

metadata.fda_pregnancy_category: D (X for migraine prevention in pregnancy)

contraindications: Hepatic disease or significant hepatic dysfunction
Mitochondrial disorders caused by POLG mutations

items: Acute treatment of manic or mixed episodes in bipolar disorder

sections.text: Increases brain concentrations of gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) by inhibiting GABA transaminase, modulates voltage-gated sodium channels, and influences T-type calcium channels, stabilizing neuronal firing.

adult.mania: Initial 750 mg/day in divided doses; titrate rapidly to clinical effect; therapeutic serum level: 50–125 mcg/mL
adult.maintenance: Adjust to maintain serum levels within target range
adult.migraine: 250 mg twice daily, may increase to 1000 mg/day
adult.epilepsy: 10–15 mg/kg/day, increase by 5–10 mg/kg/week; max 60 mg/kg/day

sections.geriatric: Start at lower dose, monitor closely for sedation and hepatic function
sections.renal_impairment: No adjustment needed, but monitor protein binding and free valproate

sections.text: Onset for mania control is usually within a few days; steady state is reached in 2–4 days; half-life ranges 9–16 hours.

sections.black_box: Hepatotoxicity, pancreatitis, teratogenicity; contraindicated in pregnancy for migraine prophylaxis.
other: Caution in patients with mitochondrial disorders
Avoid abrupt discontinuation to prevent seizure risk

items.risk: Increased lamotrigine levels and risk of rash

items: Liver function tests at baseline and regularly
Ammonia levels if altered mental status

sections.pregnancy: Contraindicated for migraine prophylaxis; high teratogenic risk; avoid unless no alternatives
sections.lactation: Excreted in breast milk; weigh benefits and risks
sections.pediatrics: Approved for seizure disorders; caution for hepatotoxicity in children under 2
sections.geriatrics: More sensitive to sedation and tremor; monitor closely

sections.text: Taper gradually over weeks to prevent relapse or seizure recurrence.

items: Monitor weight and metabolic parameters during long-term use
Educate patients about early symptoms of liver or pancreas problems
